awd_titl_txt: Spin Polarization Spectroscopy in Organic Semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: As the miniaturization of electronic circuits approaches its limitation, there is a need to find alternative ways to generate, manipulate, transfer and detect information while reducing the energy needed for such operations. One approach to achieve this is to use the magnetic behavior of electrons, otherwise known as spin. Using the spin in order to implement such a new type of information processing is called "spintronics". The research in this project focuses on studying physical mechanisms that allow for spintronics in carbon-based, so-called organic semiconductors. These studies include in particular the control and manipulation, the transport and the very sensitive detection of magnetic phenomena in thin plastic films. Spintronics devices based on such novel materials are engineered, fabricated and tested using electrical, magnetic and optical measurements. In addition, the integration of the large arsenal of experimental efforts serves to efficiently educate graduate and undergraduate students participating in these interdisciplinary research projects. Separately, the research team is also reaching out to pre-college students in order to inform them on career opportunities and the technological potential of the Physical and Natural Sciences.
 
Technical description: The goal of this project is to improve the understanding of electron spin polarization effects in organic semiconductors with tunable strength of the spin-orbit coupling. Specifically, the project aims to develop an understanding of the physical nature of spin transport in this materials class. The research is focused on spin polarized charge carrier ensembles using two spin-polarization techniques: (i) spin-pumping by resonantly generated spin-waves in ferromagnetic substrates, which is detected by the inverse spin-Hall effect; and (ii) thermally induced equilibrium spin-polarization obtained from high magnetic fields at cryogenic temperatures, which is detected by field-induced circular polarization emission. Spintronics devices such as spin-valves, spin-diodes, and spin organic light emitting diodes are engineered, fabricated and tested using electrical, magnetic and optical means. This project integrates the University of Utah's large arsenal of experimental capabilities, including polymer and small molecule deposition, magneto-transport, electrically-detected ferromagnetic resonance, magnon-related spin-pumping, modeling as well as device fabrication, processing and testing. Together, these unfold the broad impact of an entirely new class of electronics for educating a cadre of graduate and undergraduate students who are involved in the execution of this project, and the outreach that is made to local High School and Middle School communities.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes

This project was focused on the study of spin transport mechanisms for pure spin currents in organic semiconductors (OSECs), i.e. the ability of these materials to allow the flow of magnetization, in absence of flow of electric charges, i.e. electric current. This experimental study focused on so-called spin pumping measurements, where ferromagnetic (FM) resonantly driven magnetic materials are used to inject a pure spin-current into a non-magnetic material, which is then observed via the inverse-spin-Hall effect, where the spin current is converted into charge current. The experiments conducted in the course of this measurement showed that the spin transport in OSEC is very different than charge transport. Spin transport in OSECs is much faster since it does not need the physical propagation of charge carriers. Additional goals that were achieved in the course of this project was the demonstration of spin pumping using an organic-based magnet, and the development of an understanding of major spin interactions of photoexcitations in OSEC films and devices.

This project was executed by using three main experimental concepts: (i) spin pumping into OSEC films by spin-waves from FM substrates; (ii) spin polarization of photoexcitations induced by circular polarized light; (iii) Magnetic field effect measurements of OSEC films and devices. The efforts have been augmented by the PIs’ complementary expertise in the areas of organic and inorganic electronics, as well as the synergies which came out of the collaboration between the two research groups of the PIs at the University of Utah (UofU). Together, the team working on this project demonstrated the ability of an organic ferromagnet to inject spin into a non-magnetic metal (Pt) by the process of spin pumping.  

This project leveraged the results, student training, and infrastructure that have been accumulated in the PIs’ laboratories for offering collaborative, interdisciplinary research opportunities, and a stimulating environment for training in diverse skill sets. The research has spanned the area of thin-film deposition of various OSECs and ferromagnetic injectors (including an organic FM); the structural and physical characterization of OSEC and organic magnets; spin-related device design, fabrication and characterization and related measurement techniques such as various magnetic resonance methods, spin injection, spin-pumping and Brillouin light scattering techniques. As a result, the project led to the following intellectual merit: (i) A basic understanding of spin transport in OSEC films and devices has been developed; (ii) Spin-dependent processes of photoexcitations in films and electrically injected charges in OSEC devices have been discovered and understood; (iii) A basic understanding of spin injection from ferromagnetic and otherwise magnetically ordered materials into OSEC films and devices has been developed; (iv) The independence of spin- and charge transport in OSECs has been established; (v) The availability of organic magnets as high-quality spin injector material in magnetic/non-magnetic bilayer structures has been demonstrated.

Broader Impact: Our studies have affected the modern high-tech society due to the potential development of new spintronics applications. The PIs have dedicated much educational effort based on the progress of this highly interdisciplinary project on the involved undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral associates. Furthermore, various activities aimed to establish equitable access by all societal groups to natural sciences have been done such as a continued involvement of the PIs in the UofU ACCESS program; as well various UofU summer undergraduate research programs. The PIs have also disseminated their results via scientific publications, presentations and reviews and gave lectures and demonstrations for the broader public.
